About me

I’m a computer scientist with a rich academic background that has taken me from Asia to North America. My journey began at the Communication University of China, where I earned my undergraduate degree in Computer Science, continued at New York University for my Master’s, and culminated with a PhD from Dartmouth College, which I completed in 2024.
During my PhD at the Minds, Machines, and Society (MMS) lab at Dartmouth College, I actively engaged in collaborations with scholars from diverse fields such as computational biology, psychology, and sociology. I am sincerely grateful of the opportunity to work with my advisor, Prof. Soroush Vosoughi.
I also had the chance to visit Stanford University, hosted by Professor Diyi Yang, and University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, where I worked with Professor Heng Ji. I thrive in collaborative and interdisciplinary research environments.

I am currently on the job market, actively seeking opportunities to contribute to academia!

My research is centered on enhancing the interpretability of natural language processing (NLP) models and using these insights to improve their capabilities and safety. I am also dedicated to expanding the applicability of NLP technologies across various disciplines, including multimodal processing, computational biology, and computational sociology. Check out my selected papers in the Publications tab for more information.

Collaborations of all forms are welcome and greatly appreciated. Drop me an email!

Weicheng Ma

  • (2024) Ph.D. in CS, Dartmouth
  • (2015) M.S. in CS, NYU
  • (2013) B.S. in CS, CUC
